docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Hezbollah Takes Charge In Reconstruction Effort Hezbollah took charge of reconstruction efforts in dozens of villages in Lebanon, cleaning, organizing and surveying the damage from the war with Israel, as it increasingly seemed that the militant Shiite group's reputation would grow in the hearts of Lebanese returning to their shattered homes. A1 Israel began to pull many of its reserve troops out of southern Lebanon and hopes to be out of the country altogether in the next week or 10 days, the military chief of staff said. A8 Hope and Caution in AIDS Fight An array of promising new methods to prevent the spread of H.I.V. may become a reality in the near future, but most countries are unprepared to provide them to the hundreds of millions of people at risk of becoming infected, a panel said at the 16th International Conference on AIDS. A6 The Deadliest Month in Iraq July appears to have been the deadliest month of the war for Iraqi civilians, according to figures from the Health Ministry and the Baghdad morgue, reinforcing criticism that the Baghdad security plan started in June by the new Iraqi government has failed. A10 President Bush made clear in a meeting this week that he was concerned about the lack of progress in Iraq and frustrated that the new Iraqi government had not shown more public support for the American mission, participants in the meeting said. A10 Taliban Arrests in Pakistan Pakistani police officers arrested 29 Taliban fighters in a hospital in the city of Quetta, the Interior Ministry said. The arrests came after pressure from NATO countries on Pakistan to do more to round up Taliban fighters. A10 Fallout From Plane Plot British authorities said they had made another arrest in the reported plot to blow up trans-Atlantic airplanes, but delays, cancelations and missing baggage still plagued London's airports and a debate broke out over concerns about the use of racial profiling during passenger screening. A11 NATIONAL A12-15 Pluto Remains a Planet As New Rules Are Debated In the hope of ending years of wrangling, a committee of astronomers and historians has proposed a new definition of the word ''planet'' that would expand the family of planets from 9 to 12 and cause textbooks and the charts in thousands of classrooms to be out of date. A1 Schiavo Enters Political Debate Michael Schiavo, who last year won the legal battle to remove his brain-damaged wife Terri's feeding tube, has formed a political action committee, called TerriPAC, aimed at politicians who tried to stop her death. A15 Medicare Drug Premium Steady Federal officials announced that the average premium for Medicare prescription drug coverage next year would be about $24 a month, which is the same as this year and 40 percent less than originally estimated for 2007. A12 G.O.P. Scrambles to Save Seat With dwindling hopes of keeping Tom DeLay's longtime House seat from falling to a Democrat in November, Texas Republicans called an urgent meeting for tomorrow to exercise their only option: agreeing on a write-in candidate. A12 Wyoming Wildfire Grows Thousands of residents were evacuated as a fast-growing wildfire threatened high-altitude homes and populous suburban subdivisions. More than 7,000 acres burned as the fire swept across Casper Mountain. A12 State Fair Budgets in the Red Attendance at state fairs has dropped sharply across the nation's midsection in recent years. The problems have grown severe enough to lead some political leaders to question the wisdom of spending tax money to keep the fairs afloat. A1 Man-Made Grass Escapes Lab An unapproved type of genetically engineered grass has been found growing in the wild in what scientists say could be the first instance in the United States in which a biotechnology plant has established itself outside a farm. A13 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 With Retooled Campaign, Lieberman In Race to Stay Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut is remaining in the race for the Senate as an independent candidate despite his defeat to Ned Lamont in the Democratic primary, and some Washington Democrats feel that a Lieberman win in the general election is a distinct possibility. A1 Attorney General Resigns Zulima V. Farber, the attorney general of New Jersey, resigned after a state investigation found that she had violated her own department's code of ethics by going to the aid of her companion during a routine traffic stop. A1 EDUCATION B7 College Board Expands The College Board has broadened its ambitions by marketing new products and starting five ''College Board schools,'' with plans to open 13 more. The board says it is eager to bring new rigor to education, but it is also driven because it is no longer an unrivaled force. A1 DINING IN F1-10 Food Web Site Aims Younger Chow.com, a food Web site expected to launch next week, hopes to inject a hip sensibility into its coverage of the marketing and culture of food. All this is aimed at a younger audience than the major food Web sites tend to attract. F1 OBITUARIES C12 Leonard H. Marks A communications lawyer who helped Lyndon B. Johnson acquire the television stations that built their fortune and who later served as director of the United States Information Agency in the Johnson administration, he was 90. C12 Joseph F. Carlino A leading Long Island Republican for 20 years and the speaker of the New York State Assembly from 1959 to 1964, he was 89. C12 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 Judge Rules for Insurers A federal judge in Mississippi sided with home insurance companies and ruled that they do not have to pay for the flooding that destroyed tens of thousands of homes in Hurricane Katrina. C1 Inflation Data Lifts Stocks Wall Street rallied after a government report that showed inflation softening at the wholesale level encouraged hopes among investors that the Federal Reserve may be able to avoid further interest rate increases. C1 The Limits of Batteries Science is confronting the limits of the batteries that power millions of portable consumer electronics. The more energy that is stored in a small package, the more volatile and dangerous that package becomes. C1 BAE Seeks U.S. Expansion BAE, the British military contractor, says it is neither British nor American, but a new breed of military contractor -- a trans-Atlantic supplier. The chief executive has even hinted he might move the company to the United States if he gets more Pentagon business. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A16-17 Editorials: Meanwhile, in Iraq; now some good news; a discouraging word; of math proofs and millionaires. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E6 Weather D7 TV Listings E9
